On Sat, 1 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:

> Again, the simplicity of the code example had nothing to do with the
> original thread, which was about how to unit test certain predicaments
> people code themselves into (or inherit from someone else).

I thought I addressed the point quite directly: make this simple change to
the code and you'll be able to test it easily.

> > My concern is not about shipping it with the product; my concern is
> > that, whether it ships or not, it's extra code to write and maintain.
>
> Like I said, there's no reason it couldn't be reused.

Sure. But even just doing the setup on that object is still more code
than simply not testing it.

I don't feel I'll ever get any payback from that test; that is to say, I
don't think it would ever fail. Thus, I don't write the test. If I ever
start getting bitten by bugs in that sort of code, I'll realize that
my prediction in this type of case is sometimes wrong, and I'll start
writing those tests.

(Only tests that ever fail at some point pay back their investment; the
tests that never fail never catch any bugs, and are thus a waste of time
and money. It's just our lack of perfect knowledge about what's going
to fail in the future that forces us to waste time and money. XP's unit
testing strategy, as I see it, tries to maximize the overall return on
the test investment.)

> Another idea, borrowed from Kent Beck's latest book on TDD, is SelfShunt,
> where you have the TestCase itself be a kind of mock object, implementing
> the interface of whatever class your class under test expects to interact
> with.

I've done that. I've also just created anonymous objects on the fly.
Both are good ideas, though orthogonal to the discussion above of
whether or not one should test something in the first place.

> "I would predict that the strategy listed above, while good intentioned, on
> a project of any size would wind up with lots of extra code throughout added
> just for testability.

It's not lots of extra code. I added, in my example, two extra lines of
code: a method declaration and a method call. Another line was extracted
from the other method, and so existed anyway. (I'm not counting the lone
closing brace or the extra whitespace lines as lines of code.)

I think that you would probably have added the same amount of code to
the test case just to set up the mock connection factory, not to mention
introducing another object into the system rather than just an extra
method, making things more complex rather than less. IMHO, of course.

> Testability is an aspectual concern, not really a part of an object being
> modeled.

I disagree. Maybe it comes from seeing engineers design buildings and
similar structures: it turns out that you design them not only so that
they fulfill their intended function after you're done building them,
but also so that they have good "buildability." They'll add in stuff
that has no relevance to the final function simply to make it faster,
cheaper or easier to build. This was a pretty stunning concept to me
when I first found out about it, because it was something I'd never
considered before.

So now, always, testability is high on my list of things I consider when
I design any system. I usually am expected to provide some way of showing,
on a continuous basis, that the system will do what's expected of it, so
it's really almost a final function of the system in the same way that
the behaviour the client is looking for is a final function of it.
